utterance.speaker: JOE MCUSIC
utterance.content: Help me! Help me! Help-- me--

utterance.speaker: JUDGE FITZ
utterance.content: Order. Order! Call the paramedics.

utterance.speaker: MAN
utterance.content: Come here and help.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Are you trying to kill me? What's in this?

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Everything you need for a healthier and longer life.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: What is the sense in living longer if you have to drink that?

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Ah, that's the stuff.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Ugh.

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: Good morning.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Good morning, darling.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Hey. Hey, why aren't you in school?

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: It's faculty development day.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Perfect, because do you know what's playing at the Angelika? Forbidden Planet, Leslie Nielsen long before his comic glory. Do you remember how much you used to love this?

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: Mm-hmm.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Want to go with me?

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: I'm sorry, I can't. I made plans to spend the day in the Village.

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: Mm, delicious. Um, bye, Grams.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: Bye, Dad.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Bye.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Ahh.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Mother, did you see that? Alexis lied.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: She did not. She loves my breakfast smoothies.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: No, no. Not about that. About where she's going today. Her nose crinkled. That's her tell.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Oh, honey, come on. This is not the World Series of Poker.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I'm telling you, she's up to something. What about you? You want to go to the movies?

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: No can do, kiddo. Got to meet with my contractor at the studio.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Well, then it looks like I'm going by myself.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Or maybe...not at all. For Richard Castle, press one.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Why were there news vans out front?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Because of who our victim is. Joe McUsic.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Who?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Juror Number Seven in the Lila Addison case.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: The Addison case! Seriously, what happened?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: He dropped dead during the closing argument. Lanie thinks that he was poisoned.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Heir to the Addison fortune is murdered and, during the trial, a juror is murdered as well. This has all the makings of a John Grisham novel.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: What are you doing?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I'm, uh, texting my poker group, calling dibs on this story.

utterance.speaker: LANIE
utterance.content: It was poison, all right. Pink lividity, the smell of bitter almonds. Test strip came back positive for cyanide.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Cyanide? That is fantastic.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Unless you're the juror.

utterance.speaker: LANIE
utterance.content: There were no puncture marks on the body, so it was ingested.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: That's an odd way to kill.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Not for Nazis or evil dictators.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: How did he ingest it?

utterance.speaker: LANIE
utterance.content: Brownish stains in his mouth indicate he recently had coffee. Maybe it was in there.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: After he consumed the poison, how long before he died?

utterance.speaker: LANIE
utterance.content: No more than fifteen minutes. According to the court clerk, Mr. McUsic arrived this morning at 8:37, and died at approximately 9:13.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Fifteen minutes. That means that he was poisoned at the courthouse.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Mm-hmm. And who benefits from a dead juror?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: The defendant.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Then we agree.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: The defendant. Otis Williams. This guy's a real dirt bag's dirt bag.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Grand theft auto, aggravated assault, attempted murder.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Dirt bag trifecta. Which means, if convicted, he'd go away for a long time.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Life without parole. I bet the D.A. would ask for the needle if New York still had the death penalty.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: They caught him in a stolen car with Lila Addison's body in the trunk. They got his fingerprints, traces of the victim's blood. This guy's way past guilty.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: So, this is jury intimidation at its finest. You kill a juror, you not only guarantee a mistrial, but it also serves as a warning for any future jurors on a retrial. I mean, who wants to serve on a jury if there's a chance of being killed?

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: But we know Otis didn't do it. He's been incarcerated since his arrest.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: He might've had an accomplice. Whoever poisoned Joe McUsic somehow did it in this building fifteen minutes before he died.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: I'll get with security, pull the surveillance footage from all the corridors and common rooms.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: I'll talk to the jurors. Someone might've seen something.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: All right.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Why don't we what Mr. Otis Williams has to say for himself? Counselor! Detective Beckett. I'd like to speak with your client.

utterance.speaker: ATTORNEY NICK KELLER
utterance.content: Detective, anything we have to say about Lila Addison, we've said during the trial.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: I'm not here about Miss Addison. I'm here about Juror Number Seven.

utterance.speaker: ATTORNEY NICK KELLER
utterance.content: Okay, what about him?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: He was murdered.

utterance.speaker: ATTORNEY NICK KELLER
utterance.content: Murdered? I thought he died of a seizure or some other natural cause.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: There's nothing natural about cyanide poisoning.

utterance.speaker: ATTORNEY NICK KELLER
utterance.content: Okay, look. My client doesn't know anything about that, and there's no way I'm letting him talk to you. Now, if you'll excuse us, we're due in court. Let's go.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE FITZ
utterance.content: In light of the shocking circumstances of Juror Number Seven's death, it is my belief that this particular jury is no longer capable of reaching a fair verdict. Therefore, I have no choice but to declare a mistrial.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE FITZ
utterance.content: Noted. Until then, Mr. Williams will be remanded. This hearing is adjourned.

utterance.speaker: RANDOLPH ADDISON
utterance.content: You call this justice, Your Honor?! After what he did to my daughter?!

utterance.speaker: RANDOLPH ADDISON
utterance.content: You monster.

utterance.speaker: STEPHEN ADDISON
utterance.content: Dad! Dad. Don't. Let's go home.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Looks like Otis's plan is working.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Yeah, for now.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Ryan, you find anything yet?

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Not yet. The building has a lot of cameras. Even though we have a very narrow time frame, it's gonna take a couple hours to get through all of it.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Maybe we're wrong about the defendant. Maybe we should be looking at a juror.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: What do you mean?

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Tony Mueller, Juror Number Four. He's been missing since the murder. He was no show for one of our interviews, he's not answering his cell, and neighbors saw him leave his apartment with an overnight bag.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: All right, keep an eye out for him on the video.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: I already got an APB out on him.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Oh, you do?

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Mm-hmm.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Good.

utterance.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: Beckett. The brother of your dead juror's here.

utterance.speaker: EDDIE MCUSIC
utterance.content: Thought courtrooms were supposed to be safe.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: I'm so sorry, Mr. McUsic. We're doing everything we can to figure it out.

utterance.speaker: EDDIE MCUSIC
utterance.content: Man, who would want to hurt Joe?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Well, you know, it might not have to do with your brother. It might have to do with the jury that he served on. Did you know that he was assigned to the Addison trial?

utterance.speaker: EDDIE MCUSIC
utterance.content: No. No, I just knew he had jury duty.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Can you think of any reasons why your brother might've been biased either toward or against the defendant?

utterance.speaker: EDDIE MCUSIC
utterance.content: When he was a kid, my brother had a few scrapes with the law. But he cleaned his life up. He believed in second chances. That's why he ran the halfway house. What he didn't believe in were third, fourth, fifth chances. He'd been out there long enough to know some folks can't be rehabilitated.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Do you know if your brother had any problems with anyone at work? I mean, given the kinds of people that he dealt with.

utterance.speaker: EDDIE MCUSIC
utterance.content: No. Joe had a way with folks. He'd look out for people.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Do you think Joe was chosen at random? Or do you think he was killed because of his background?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Well, since this isn't, in fact, a Grisham novel, I thought I'd keep an open mind. Hey, Ryan, can you look into Joe McUsic's halfway house, see if he had any problems with anyone there?

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: I already spoke with his staff. They don't remember any conflicts, but they're sending over a list of residents in case.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Yo. Our missing juror? Troopers picked him up crossing the GW Bridge. They're bringing him in now.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: You were leaving town in a hurry, Mr. Mueller. Any reason why?

utterance.speaker: TONY MUELLER
utterance.content: Isn't it obvious? I'm marked for death, man.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Marked for death?

utterance.speaker: TONY MUELLER
utterance.content: I didn't ask for jury duty. I was summoned. They said show up at this time at this place. They failed to mention that the defendant's homeboy was gonna kill me.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: The defendant's homeboy?

utterance.speaker: TONY MUELLER
utterance.content: Yeah. This big, scary, black guy.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Exactly what happened, Mr. Mueller?

utterance.speaker: TONY MUELLER
utterance.content: Yesterday, this guy follows me into the courthouse bathroom and starts chatting me up about the trial.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Did he give you his name?

utterance.speaker: TONY MUELLER
utterance.content: No. No, but he's going on and on about how Otis Williams is innocent, and how he's being railroaded by the system. And then this morning, I see the same guy on the defendant's side of the gallery in the front row, eyeballing me.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Have you ever seen him with Joe?

utterance.speaker: TONY MUELLER
utterance.content: Yes! Which is why, when I saw Joe bite it right in front of me, I knew I was next! And why should I die? I was only trying to fulfill my civic responsibilities!

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Thank you for coming in, Mr. Mueller. Now, do you think you'll be able to describe to our sketch artist?

utterance.speaker: TONY MUELLER
utterance.content: He--he's a big, scary, black guy.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: It might help if you're just a little more specific.

utterance.speaker: TONY MUELLER
utterance.content: Uh, okay. Um, well-- like I said, he's a-- he's a big, he's-- scary, black guy...named Wardell Williams, the defendant's cousin.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: I didn't-- I thought you didn't know who he was.

utterance.speaker: TONY MUELLER
utterance.content: I didn't, but there he is!

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: W-- are-- are you sure?

utterance.speaker: TONY MUELLER
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: While you guys were in the box with Mr. Mueller, I found this on courthouse surveillance. See, that's Joe the juror at the coffee machine roughly fourteen minutes before his death, right in our kill zone.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Cousin Wardell.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: And watch this.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Looks like he makes a killer cup of joe.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Too soon.

utterance.speaker: WARDELL WILLIAMS
utterance.content: You're not trying to accuse me of murder with this half-assed version of a Zapruder film?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: You and Otis were more than just cousins. Grew up in the same household. More like brothers.

utterance.speaker: WARDELL WILLIAMS
utterance.content: Yeah, me and O tight. So, what?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: So, it makes sense you'd do anything for him, including kill a juror on his murder trial.

utterance.speaker: WARDELL WILLIAMS
utterance.content: Man, y'all reaching.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Are we? You talked to jurors. That's jury tampering.

utterance.speaker: WARDELL WILLIAMS
utterance.content: So, accusing one black man of a murder he didn't commit isn't good enough for you. What, y'all trying for the deadly double? And I talked to a gang of folks in that courthouse. How'm I supposed to know which one of them is a juror?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Well, the juror badges on their shirts might've been a hint.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Using video surveillance footage, CSU managed to pull Joe's coffee cup out of the garbage. They're testing it for cyanide. Why don't you just come clean while we still got a deal to make.

utterance.speaker: WARDELL WILLIAMS
utterance.content: Man, I told you! I ain't do nothing!

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Wardell, sit down! Before I make you sit down.

utterance.speaker: WARDELL WILLIAMS
utterance.content: So, obviously, you must be the bad cop. Guess that makes you the good cop.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Actually, I'm not a cop.

utterance.speaker: WARDELL WILLIAMS
utterance.content: Oh, you not a cop?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Mr. Castle is a writer. He consults with the department on occasion.

utterance.speaker: WARDELL WILLIAMS
utterance.content: Oh. So, that's how you two do it.

utterance.speaker: WARDELL WILLIAMS
utterance.content: You tell the lies--

utterance.speaker: WARDELL WILLIAMS
utterance.content: --you print the lies? Man, y'all framing me just like they did my cousin. Man, this whole damn thing's a conspiracy.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Wardell, be serious.

utterance.speaker: WARDELL WILLIAMS
utterance.content: 'Ch'y'on't think I'm serious? Then tell me why, of all the lawyers in the city, the District Attorney is trying Otis' case? You don't think it's 'cause he's running for mayor and he wants to lock my cousin up so all his rich, powerful, white friends can feel safe?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Look, you're not doing yourself any favors right now.

utterance.speaker: WARDELL WILLIAMS
utterance.content: Now, you just got it all worked out, huh? Man, you got my cousin, O, pulling a bigger Thomas. And you got me poisoning this man to get him off.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Looks that way.

utterance.speaker: WARDELL WILLIAMS
utterance.content: Well, looks don't make it so. Looks like I'm poisoning this man's coffee. And really, all I did was hand it to him.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Hey, Esposito.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Mm?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Can you get a warrant for Wardell's place? See if there's any traces of cyanide.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: You got it.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: And, as they say in legalese, asked and answered. It's too bad. I was hoping there would be a little more to the story than that.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Hmm.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: "Hmm," what?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Alexis said she'd be in the Village today, but she's over in Williamsburg.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Well, how do you know she's in Williamsburg?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: GPS tracked her phone.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: You tracked her phone?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Yeah, super cool app I just downloaded. I can see where she is at any time.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Does she know that you're doing this?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: What, are you kidding? No, she'd kill me.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: And be justified.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I'm her father. If something's going on, I--I need to know. A lot of parents will go through their kids' drawers or computers.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Far less intrusive.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Beckett.

utterance.speaker: LANIE
utterance.content: Joe's cyanide laced coffee cup. CSU found both Joe and Wardell's prints on it, but there was something very important missing. Cyanide.

utterance.speaker: LANIE
utterance.content: Really.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Well, how was he poisoned?

utterance.speaker: LANIE
utterance.content: During the autopsy, I discovered cyanide residue in a prescription time-release capsule.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: So, Joe had a prescription for cyanide?

utterance.speaker: LANIE
utterance.content: No. He had a prescription for corticosteroids. According to his physician, he took one every morning for symptoms from lupus. It looks like the killer switched out the contents of Joe's capsule, and replaced it with the cyanide.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Okay. So then, when Joe was taking his medications, he unknowingly poisoned himself.

utterance.speaker: LANIE
utterance.content: But here's the rub. Since the cyanide was in a time-release capsule designed not to dissolve in stomach acid, but in the intestines--

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Our timeline is all screwed up.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Ugh.

utterance.speaker: LANIE
utterance.content: Yep. Turns out Joe was poisoned almost one hour before his death, at 8:13 this morning.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: That's before he even got to the courthouse.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Which means the killer probably wasn't there, either.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: So then, Joe's death might not have anything to do with the trial.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Well, we learned three very important things. Firstly, our killer is diabolical. You let someone unwittingly kill themselves? Pure evil. Second, our killer knew Joe, or at least knew his habits. Third, our killer was a woman.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Hmm?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Statistically speaking, poisonings are almost always carried out by the fairer sex.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Ah, but you are missing one very important detail, Castle.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Enlighten me.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Our killer had access to Joe's medications. Medications that he did not keep on him. So, therefore, our killer had access to--

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: His apartment.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Bingo.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: NYPD.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: You know, the murder of Joe the juror is a real tragedy.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Isn't every murder a tragedy?

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Yes, every murder's a tragedy, but Joe is special. He was a juvenile delinquent who reformed himself. A born again citizen who believed in the system and helped out ex-cons. And what did he get for his trouble?

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Hmm. Pill full of poison.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Mm-hmm.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: "Cowards die many times before their death, the valiant never taste of death but once."

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Bro, you're not Castle.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Yeah, I know I'm not Castle.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Then stop trying to talk like him.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: What? I'm not allowed to reference the Bard?

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: I'm a renaissance man.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Memorizing one quote does not make you a renaissance man.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: What if I memorize two?

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Have you memorized two?

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: No, but what if I did?

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Depends on the quote.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Now, who the hell are you?

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Hank Ponzell, former resident of Joe McUsic's halfway house. Until you were kicked out when Joe denied your extension.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: That had to make you mad, huh, Hank?

utterance.speaker: HANK PONZELL
utterance.content: You don't understand.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Oh, no, I think we do. Joe kicked you to the curb and you poisoned him. Lab report shows that every one of these capsules tested positive for cyanide.

utterance.speaker: HANK PONZELL
utterance.content: If I poisoned him, why would I still be in his apartment?

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: To take the rest of the poison and pills away, so we couldn't find them, so you could hide your tracks.

utterance.speaker: HANK PONZELL
utterance.content: I was out of the apartment all day. Anyone could've gotten in there. And I would never hurt Joe. He was my friend.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Friends like him, huh?

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Right.

utterance.speaker: HANK PONZELL
utterance.content: I didn't poison him. Joe was letting me stay there, okay? I maxed out my time at the halfway house and didn't have a place to go. Joe broke the rules and let me crash with him.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Then why were you playing hide and go seek in his closet?

utterance.speaker: HANK PONZELL
utterance.content: I'm a felon on parole. I hear cops and my ex-con instincts kick in.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Okay. If you were there on the up and up, tell us, was Joe in any kind of trouble?

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Look, buddy, I don't think you appreciate the situation you're in. You are on parole, and you're up to your neck in a homicide investigation. Now, you better start talking, or we're gonna have you back in Sing Sing before the evening roll call.

utterance.speaker: HANK PONZELL
utterance.content: All right. Joe had me run errands for him, okay? Pick up laundry, go to bodegas, stuff like that. A few weeks ago, he gave me an envelope and told me to take it to this lady.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: What was in the envelope?

utterance.speaker: HANK PONZELL
utterance.content: Cash. Like two grand. But I don't know what it was for, I swear. Joe always talked about how he got out of the criminal life, but maybe he still had a foot in.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Who was this lady that you delivered the envelope to?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Miss Jenkins?

utterance.speaker: SANDY JENKINS
utterance.content: Yes?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Do you live at 3751 West End Ave?

utterance.speaker: SANDY JENKINS
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: We need to chat.

utterance.speaker: SANDY JENKINS
utterance.content: I did it. I did it, I did it.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: You killed him?

utterance.speaker: SANDY JENKINS
utterance.content: Oh, my God, no! Of course not! Why would you think that?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Because you just said, "I did it."

utterance.speaker: SANDY JENKINS
utterance.content: Oh, no, no, not murder. No, God. I--I did something else. Something awful.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Miss Jenkins, you're the court clerk. Why did Joe McUsic give you that much money?

utterance.speaker: SANDY JENKINS
utterance.content: He paid me to put him on that jury.

utterance.speaker: SANDY JENKINS
utterance.content: Joe McUsic came to me and said he wanted to serve his jury duty. I didn't see the harm.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Sure, I mean, especially if you're gonna make a profit.

utterance.speaker: SANDY JENKINS
utterance.content: My roommate moved out two months ago. I needed the cash for rent, and I figured, who's gonna know? I mean, it's jury duty. Please, please, don't send me to prison. All day long I-- I see the women who get sent there and I can't hack it. I'll be some lifer's ***** before breakfast.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Okay. Joe specifically asked to be on Otis Williams' trial?

utterance.speaker: SANDY JENKINS
utterance.content: Yes. He was insistent about getting on that jury pool.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Did he tell you why?

utterance.speaker: SANDY JENKINS
utterance.content: No. It was the Lila Addison case, so I figured maybe he wanted to write a tell all book about it or something. I swear, all I did was put him in the pool. He got through jury selection on his own.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Ryan and Esposito looked at Joe's computer. There's no evidence that he was writing a book or even taking notes on the trial.

utterance.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: So, our murdered juror just bought himself onto the jury, and we still have no idea why?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: A murder, a mystery, wrapped up inside a courtroom thriller? I can't believe John Grisham hasn't written this book.

utterance.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: Wish he had. Maybe then we'd know what was so special about that trial to Joe.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Well, maybe Joe had a personal connection to the trial, to the victim Lila Addison, or to the defendant, Otis Williams.

utterance.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: Doesn't Joe have a juvie record?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Mm-hmm.

utterance.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: What if he knew Otis from back in the day? They could've gotten arrested together, or maybe spent some time in the same juvenile hall.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: That's a good idea. I'll look into it.

utterance.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: Meanwhile, I'll have Lila Addison's case file sent over from seven four. And you should check in with the family. Could be a connection there.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Okay. Goodnight, Castle.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Night.

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: Hey, Dad. Writing?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Yeah. How was your day? D'you have a good time in the Village?

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Go anywhere else?

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: Uh, no. Just stayed in the Village.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Really? I mean, New York is a big city. Lots of boroughs.

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: Yeah, but I just stayed in Manhattan.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: So, you didn't go to, uh, Brooklyn? Williamsburg is beautiful this time of year.

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: How did you know?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: A friend of mine told me. You went there, he saw you.

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: What friend?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Close friend. JJ. Adams.

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: Nose twitch. That's your tell. You're lying!

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: No, I'm not.

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: Then who's JJ Adams?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: He's a friend of mine.

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: Wait. JJ Adams was Leslie Nielsen's character name in Forbidden Planet. You're totally lying! How did you know where I was? Are you having me followed? Monitoring my metro card? Checking my credit-- ? ...My phone. Dad, tell me you are not tracking my phone.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Okay, look, this is not about what I did. It's about what you did. You lied to me.

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: Says the man who violated his daughter's civil rights.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Okay, technically I would have to be the government to violate--

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: You're tracking my every move!

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Not your every move!

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: Welcome to George Orwell's 1984 with my father as Big Brother.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: This isn't about--

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: What's next? A chip in my brain?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Whatever it takes when you're keeping secrets from me.

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: You know what? If you're so interested in what I'm doing, why don't you ask your phone? I'm sure there's an app for that.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: You had it coming, Castle. I mean, you have the best kid in the world and you treated her like a common criminal.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Maybe she is, though. I still don't know why she lied about going to Williamsburg.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: And you probably never will. Unless you plan on waterboarding her.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Honestly, is what I did so wrong?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: I don't really think that it matters to Alexis. I mean, you broke her trust.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Yeah. I know. So, what do I do now?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Win it back. Come on, Lila's family's waiting.

utterance.speaker: RANDOLPH ADDISON
utterance.content: No, I've never seen him outside of the jury box. Then again, he was a...

utterance.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: Mr. Addison, is it at all possible that your daughter knew this man?

utterance.speaker: RANDOLPH ADDISON
utterance.content: No. Stephen?

utterance.speaker: STEPHEN ADDISON
utterance.content: I know most of my sister's friends. He's not one of them. And if he was, why would he have done this? Why would he put my sister's shot at justice in jeopardy?

utterance.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: How bad are things, Lou?

utterance.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: All the years I've been in command of the Twelfth Precinct, you know how many times the District Attorney has shown up? Once. Today. You heard the man, let's get to work.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Yes, sir.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: There is no Joe connection to Lila Addison. There's nothing in her financials, her murder file, her e-mails, her texts, not even her yearbook. Joe and Lila have absolutely nothing in common.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: It's like the two of them didn't even live on the same planet.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Same goes with Joe and Otis.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: There's no Joe connection in the juvie files?

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: No. Not even close. Joe and Otis were sent to different juvie halls at different times and they ran in opposite neighborhoods.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: So, why the hell did he want to get on that jury so bad?

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Wait a minute. I think I got something.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: You have a connection?

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: According to his credit card, Joe purchased a pay-as-you-go cell phone from an electronics store a couple months back.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: So?

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: So, he already had a cell phone. What's he need a burner phone for? Especially an anonymous one. And if he is using it, where is it?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: All right, take a crew to his apartment, see what you can find. That might be the break that we need.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Castle? Castle, can you stop playing around?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Actually, I'm not playing around. I'm a little busy blowing this case wide open. This is a photograph of the Lookie-Lous at Lila's crime scene. This has a little magnification app.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Recognize anyone?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: It's Joe! He was at Lila Addison's crime scene.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Why would he be there?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Only three reasons for a civilian to be at a murder scene. One, they're dead. Two, they just happen to be in the immediate area. Or three, it's our killer and he couldn't resist the compulsion to return to the scene of the crime. And which number do you think Joe is?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: I'm gonna go with three.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: He's our victim and our killer.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Nice.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Ah.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Sorry.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Joe McUsic, victim and killer? This is the best twist yet. Joe served on the jury of a murder he committed.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Yeah, but if Joe literally got away with murder, why would he risk it all and bribe his way onto the jury?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Maybe he felt compelled to save an innocent man. Maybe he wanted to create reasonable doubt in the deliberation room to get Otis off, just like Henry Fonda in Twelve Angry Men.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Or maybe he got onto the jury because he wanted to make sure that an innocent Otis got convicted of his crime.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: No, I like my killer with a conscience theory better.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Yeah, well, like your theory all you want. Mine is less convoluted and contrived.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Hate to burst bubbles, but you're both wrong. Joe didn't kill Lila. He had an alibi. I did background on the halfway house. On the night Lila was killed, Joe was at a fundraiser.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: He was there until midnight.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: And Lila was killed between 9:30 and 11:30 p.m.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: So, if he didn't kill her, why did he want to be on the jury so bad?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: And why was he at the crime scene?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Okay, so we know that Joe was a juror with a hidden agenda. He was embroiled in a high profile case being tried by the D.A. himself. But before he could accomplish what he set out to do, he was struck down by powerful, shadowy forces.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: There's gotta be something that we're missing. There has to be a tangible connection between Joe and our defendant, or Joe and our victim.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Or between Joe and somebody else entirely. I found the phone. It was hiding behind some books in the bookcase. Joe made fourteen calls with it, all to the same number. District Attorney Lou Karnacki's office.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Looks like the D.A. was out of order.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Mrs. Craig--

utterance.speaker: DAWN CRAIG
utterance.content: Oh, please, call me Dawn.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Dawn, you are the District Attorney's administrative assistant?

utterance.speaker: DAWN CRAIG
utterance.content: Yes, ever since he came into office.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Do you remember ever receiving any phone calls from a Joe McUsic?

utterance.speaker: DAWN CRAIG
utterance.content: Ooh. Uh...we get hundreds of calls every day, and that name doesn't sound familiar.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: We have reason to believe he called numerous times. He may have said it was regarding the Otis Williams case.

utterance.speaker: DAWN CRAIG
utterance.content: Oh, uh, yeah, I did get a series of bizarre anonymous calls from a man claiming that Otis Williams was innocent.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: That would be Joe. Did he ever speak to the D.A.?

utterance.speaker: DAWN CRAIG
utterance.content: No. I never put him through. I figured he was a wacko. You know, we get a lot of these calls and half my job is to filter out the legitimate calls from the crackpots.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Did he ever mention anything else?

utterance.speaker: DAWN CRAIG
utterance.content: Yeah, he said he had evidence that would exonerate Otis Williams and how he was gonna mail it to the District Attorney's office.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Did you ever get that package?

utterance.speaker: DAWN CRAIG
utterance.content: Not that I know of.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Uh, Dawn, most of these phone calls are under two minutes long, but then there's this one at 10:14 p.m. It's over ten minutes long. Is there any chance that you took that phone call?

utterance.speaker: DAWN CRAIG
utterance.content: Oh. No. I never stay past seven.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: How late does the D.A. work?

utterance.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: It's a fast-moving case, Lou. My team just followed the evidence where it led them.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Mr. Karnacki, Joe McUsic made several phone calls to your office; one of them lasted over ten minutes. Did you speak to him, sir?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Did he send you any evidence that was relevant to the Otis Williams case?

utterance.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: Lou. You said you wanted this murder squared away. That's all we're doing.

utterance.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: You called in the D.A.'s personal assistant without informing him?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Sir, I'm sorry. I was-- I--

utterance.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: It was a smart move. Don't you see what just happened? He could've called and asked why his assistant was here, but he came in person.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: He wanted to stop the interview.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: He's hiding something.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Wardell Williams was right. It's a-- conspiracy.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: I agree. I know, weird.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Yeah. Weird. But good, because that's just the tip of the iceberg. Are you ready for the Titanic?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Yes?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I did a little digging on the internet. Guess who the D.A.'s largest campaign contributors were on his last election?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Who?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Randolph and Andrea Addison, Lila's parents. Here's what I'm thinking. Devastated parents demand justice, insist that the D.A. try the case personally, maybe even suggest to Karnacki that he needs to put Lila's killer away in order to secure their political support.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Of course. And Karnacki agreed because it was gonna be an easy case. I mean, they already had Otis Williams. It was open and shut.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Until Joe starts calling, insisting that Otis is innocent, which is bad for Karnacki. Actually, in the end, bad for Joe.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: You know, but it's still doesn't explain why Joe bought into the jury pool or why he thought that Otis Williams was innocent. I mean, if he had exonerating evidence, where is it? We've looked everywhere. We've talked to everyone.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Not everyone.

utterance.speaker: ATTORNEY NICK KELLER
utterance.content: As I said before, we're not here to discuss the Lila Addison case.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Neither are we. We're here to talk about Joe McUsic's murder, Juror Number Seven.

utterance.speaker: ATTORNEY NICK KELLER
utterance.content: You're not still suggesting that my client had something to do with that?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Uh, we are open to the idea that Mr. Williams may not be guilty of either murder.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Look, we think that you might be able to help yourself by helping us find the real killer.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: This is Joe McUsic. Had you ever seen him before the trial?

utterance.speaker: OTIS WILLIAMS
utterance.content: Mm-mm.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: He claimed to have evidence proving your innocence. Do you have any idea what that evidence might be?

utterance.speaker: OTIS WILLIAMS
utterance.content: How am I supposed to know?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: He bought his way onto the jury in order to get you acquitted, and then he got murdered for it.

utterance.speaker: OTIS WILLIAMS
utterance.content: Well, look, I'm sorry he's dead. I appreciate my man putting himself out like that for me, but I don't know how to help y'all.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Mr. Williams, if you didn't kill Lila, then we need to figure out who did.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: You were first on the scene. Any detail you can remember, no matter how obscure, might help us.

utterance.speaker: OTIS WILLIAMS
utterance.content: A'ight. It was late. Just got off my job, you know? Walking home when I saw that sweet 760i just sitting there, keys in the ignition. I knew I should've passed it by, but I always wanted to drive a 760. So, I jumped in.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: I'm sorry, we need details. So, did you see anyone?

utterance.speaker: OTIS WILLIAMS
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Was there anything around the car?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Anything that might suggest someone else had been there? Cigarette butts? Uh, chewing gum?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Shoe prints, heel prints...

utterance.speaker: OTIS WILLIAMS
utterance.content: Nah, nothing like that.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Okay, um...what happened next?

utterance.speaker: OTIS WILLIAMS
utterance.content: I slid in the ride, pulled the seat up, hit the ignition--

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Wait, wait. Did you say that you pulled the seat up?

utterance.speaker: OTIS WILLIAMS
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Are you sure?

utterance.speaker: OTIS WILLIAMS
utterance.content: Yeah, I'm sure. That bad boy was all the way back. So, I hit the button on the side to move it up.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Lila was all of five foot nothing. There's no reason for that seat to have been all the way back.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Somebody else was driving that car. Most likely, our killer.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: And our killer would have to press the seat back button in order to move it. Did CSU check for prints?

utterance.speaker: ATTORNEY NICK KELLER
utterance.content: The steering wheel and the dash. The only prints they found were my client' s. So, when they caught him behind the wheel, I don't think they put much effort into it.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Lila's car's still at the impound pending the trial. We can still have CSU print the seat controls.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: The seat back button. What a great detail for a murder mystery.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Only if we get a print.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Yes. Otherwise, we'll just be looking for tall people.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: Dad.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Uh-- hey. Everything all right?

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: I'm sorry for yelling at you last--

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: No, no, I-- I violated your trust. I shouldn't've spied on you. It was wrong. And I want you to see this.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I am deleting that app now and forever. Okay? Gone. So...I'm sorry. Forgive me?

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: But will you forgive me?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Of course. So, tell me, what happened in Williamsburg?

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: Two days ago, a bunch of us went to Kina's of Brooklyn; it's a boutique. And my friends thought it'd be cool if we all took something a couple things.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: You shop--

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: You were shoplifting?

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: I couldn't, but my friends did and they said I was chicken.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: So, you went back to finish the job to impress your friends.

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: No, I went back to pay for what they stole. I couldn't just let someone get cheated like that. I took money out of my savings and went back to the s--tore.

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: When I got there, I put cash on the counter with a note and ran out as fast as I could.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I don't know whether to be angry or proud. What friends were you with?

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: Doesn't matter.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Well, of course it matters. How would you hang--

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: Who I was with is off the table. I'm not gonna nark on them.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Again, angry and proud. One question, though. If you didn't take anything, why did you feel responsible?

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: Because they're my friends. I guess somebody had to. It was the right thing to do.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Don't you think...they should be the ones paying--

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: Dad.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Why are you even friends with these girls in the first place?

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: It's not that simple.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: No, you're right. It never is, is it?

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: Uh, no, Detective Beckett. Stay. I was just leaving. It won't happen again, Dad. Promise.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: You okay?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Sometimes ignorance is bliss.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Mm, tell me about it.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Is that the CSU report?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Two sets of prints on the seat controls. Otis' are on the seat up button.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: And on the seat back?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Go look for yourself.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: You gotta be kidding me.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: This is the fingerprint that we pulled off of Lila Addison's car seat controls and this is your fingerprint that we have on file. They are a match.

utterance.speaker: EDDIE MCUSIC
utterance.content: There must be some mistake.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: There is no mistake. You were in Lila Addison's car the night that she was killed.

utterance.speaker: EDDIE MCUSIC
utterance.content: I didn't even know Lila.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Yeah, you did. We showed your picture around. You're a bartender at the Kiwi Seven Lounge. They pay you under the table cash.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Lila's a silent partner. You still want to go with the story that you don't know her? I think that you killed her, and then you dumped her body in her trunk.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: What you didn't count on was the guilt. You had to get it off your chest, so you told Joe. But your brother, he was an honorable man.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: He wasn't gonna rat you out, but he wasn't gonna let an innocent man go to jail for life.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: So, he called the D.A. When that didn't work, he got on the jury. But you-- you found out, and you realized you wouldn't be safe as long as he was alive.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: And then you slipped into his apartment, and you dosed his meds with cyanide.

utterance.speaker: EDDIE MCUSIC
utterance.content: Dosed his meds?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Making you the worst brother since Cane.

utterance.speaker: EDDIE MCUSIC
utterance.content: That isn't what happened.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Then what happened?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: K.

utterance.speaker: EDDIE MCUSIC
utterance.content: Whoa, wait, wha... Wait!

utterance.speaker: EDDIE MCUSIC
utterance.content: I was there, but I didn't kill her! And I didn't kill my brother! But it doesn't really matter what I say, you won't believe me anyway!

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Well, considering your other choice is murder one, I would roll the dice.

utterance.speaker: EDDIE MCUSIC
utterance.content: Stephen killed Lila. Stephen Addison, her brother. And we had talked about Joe's condition. Stephen must've seen Joe on that jury and killed him, too. Stephen and Lila were a pair of rich, spoiled coke fiends who needed to make a drug run. So, they had me drive. Stephen screwing around with this gun. This little trust fund gangster thinks he's so badass till we hit a pothole and bang!

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: The gun went off and hit Lila.

utterance.speaker: EDDIE MCUSIC
utterance.content: She died instantly. I freaked, but Stephen threatened to point the finger at me if I told the truth.

utterance.speaker: EDDIE MCUSIC
utterance.content: I'm so scared. I'm-- I'm just a nobody! He's got million dollar lawyers! We put her body in the trunk.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: And you dumped the car?

utterance.speaker: EDDIE MCUSIC
utterance.content: Stephen said, if we left it in the ghetto, the cops would think it was a carjacking gone wrong.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: And then what happened?

utterance.speaker: EDDIE MCUSIC
utterance.content: We tossed the bloody clothes in a dumpster. And I went to see Joe at his fundraiser and I told him what happened. He said we couldn't leave Lila in a trunk like that. But by the time Joe got there, the cops had already pulled over that black guy. So, Joe went to that dumpster and got Stephen's bloody clothes as insurance.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: That must be what Joe sent to the D.A.

utterance.speaker: EDDIE MCUSIC
utterance.content: It's all my fault. My brother's dead and it's all my fault.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: We can place Stephen at Lila's bar that night, but without physical evidence, all we have is Eddie's word. What do you think we should do, sir?

utterance.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: I'm sorry, Detective. Looks like there's nothing you can do.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: What are you saying? Just let them get away with it?

utterance.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: Did I say that?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Sir, where are you going?

utterance.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: To see an old friend.

utterance.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: Used my key to the city.

utterance.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: I need that package, Lou. The one Joe McUsic sent you. I know you didn't get rid of it. It's not your style, not the Louis Karnacki I know.

utterance.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: Did you know Lila Addison was murdered by her brother?

utterance.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: Guess it's good I'm not a lawyer.

utterance.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: You just put an innocent man up for murder. What's grey about that, Lou?

utterance.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: But he didn't kill Lila, Lou. He didn't kill her.

utterance.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: What? Your run for the Mayor's office?

utterance.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: Give me the package Joe McUsic sent you and I'll put in a good word for you.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Preliminary lab results indicate that Stephen's clothes had Lila's blood on it.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Eddie was telling the truth.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: And CSU found traces of cyanide in Stephen's apartment.

utterance.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: Young Mr. Addison is going down for both murders. Negligent homicide for his sister, and murder one for poisoning Joe McUsic.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: What happens to Eddie?

utterance.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: We'll charge him with accessory after the fact, but I'll push for probation. I'll call the D.A. Well, whoever the Mayor appoints as acting D.A.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Sir, I'm sorry about your friend.

utterance.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: Yeah. I mean, Lou screwed up, he did, but that doesn't take away from the good he's done.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: It's unfortunate that, despite all that good, he's only gonna be remembered for this one bad thing.

utterance.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterance.content: Nice work, you two. Goodnight.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: So, plans with Josh tonight?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: No, he's on shift. I was thinking of sneaking off to the Angelika. Forbidden Planet's playing.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Forbidden Planet, is, uh, is that the one with the robot?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: You've never seen Forbidden Planet?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: More of a Star Wars, Matrix guy myself.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Oh, my gosh. Castle, this is the movie that inspired those two. That's it, I'm taking you. My treat.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Oh, no, no. I-- I have plans.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Nope. Not anymore.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: All right, well, can I have, uh, candy and popcorn?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Sure. Oh, Castle, you're gonna love this. This is Leslie Nielsen before he became a comic genius.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Really?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Can we stop at Remy's for burgers after?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Now you're pushing it.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Oh,

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Okay. So, it starts off with this...
